newsData.title: Trade Fueled Inequality. Can Trump’s Tariffs Reduce It?
newsData.summary: The president has pitched his trade policies at workers who feel left behind by globalization. But that doesn’t mean trade barriers will revive factories and close income gaps.

newsData.title: Stock Market Posts Worst Week in Months on Renewed Economic Fears
newsData.summary: Data showing cracks in the U.S. labor market and President Trump’s newest barrage of tariffs shook investors around the world, weighing on stocks, the dollar and more.

newsData.title: Fed Governor Steps Down Early, Giving Trump Opportunity to Shape Central Bank
newsData.summary: The resignation comes as President Trump has openly pressured the central bank to lower interest rates and called for Jerome H. Powell, the chair, to step down.

newsData.title: Trump, Claiming Weak Jobs Numbers Were ‘Rigged,’ Fires Labor Official
newsData.summary: Economists said ousting the head of the Bureau of Labor Statistics could undermine confidence in government economic data.

newsData.title: How Tariffs Raise Costs for Farmers, Making Food More Expensive
newsData.summary: The latest round of tariffs is likely to make agricultural production even more expensive and, potentially, limit access to goods not produced in the United States.

newsData.title: Overturning the Global Trade System, Trump Puts His Ideas to the Test
newsData.summary: President Trump has long wanted to rework world trade. The tariffs set to go into effect next week will carry out that plan.

newsData.title: Federal Government Shed 12,000 Jobs in July
newsData.summary: The U.S. government has lost 84,000 jobs since January as the Trump administration aggressively reduces the work force.

newsData.title: Big Downward Jobs Revisions Could Be a Warning Sign for the Economy
newsData.summary: Employers added far fewer jobs in May and June than previously reported. Such downgrades have historically meant trouble for the labor market.

newsData.title: Weak Jobs Report Raises Chances of a September Interest Rate Cut
newsData.summary: The Federal Reserve held rates steady in July but two governors dissented, saying they had concerns about labor market fragility.

newsData.title: Stock Market Posts Worst Week in Months on Renewed Economic Fears
newsData.summary: Data showing cracks in the U.S. labor market and President Trump’s newest barrage of tariffs shook investors around the world, weighing on stocks, the dollar and more.

newsData.title: Switzerland Is Stunned by 39% U.S. Tariff, Among the Highest in the World
newsData.summary: Swiss officials plan to negotiate urgently for a lower rate, before the punishing levy takes effect next week.

newsData.title: Harm or Help? Why Companies Are Battling Tariffs Meant to Benefit Them.
newsData.summary: Economists say the way the Trump administration is imposing tariffs is backfiring for some of the businesses they are meant to help.

newsData.title: Cambodia Agrees to a Reduced Tariff and Breathes a Sigh of Relief
newsData.summary: Initially 49%, it was lowered to 19%, easing worries of a damaging hit to the country’s garment and footwear production industries.

newsData.title: Countries Promise Trump to Buy U.S. Gas, and Leave the Details for Later
newsData.summary: U.S. trading partners are committing to buy more gas than they need or than the U.S. can produce, at least in the short term.

newsData.title: South Korea Reaches Trade Deal With Trump
newsData.summary: The agreement comes after other American allies, like Japan, clinched their own deals, partly to moderate President Trump’s tariff threats.

newsData.title: Trump Targets Copper With Tariffs, Though Not as Aggressively as Expected
newsData.summary: The president stopped short of putting a 50 percent tariff on refined copper, as he had threatened earlier this year. The market reaction was swift anyway and prices tumbled.

newsData.title: See How Often Fed Governors Have Broken Ranks
newsData.summary: Two top Fed officials voted against the central bank’s decision to leave rates unchanged, the first dual dissent in more than 30 years.
